title: Investors wary of under-fire banks despite trade bounce
text:
IFM Investors investment director of active equities Reuben De Barros said "another formal investigation" showed that regulatory scrutiny was not "out of the way," after the Hayne royal commission.

"The new investigation reinforces the pressure on net interest margins and return on equity and that flows through to dividend pressures going forward as well."

"It's further pressure in this low interest rate environment on the top line," he said. "It's something that they really didn't need."

Treasurer Josh Frydenberg announced a new investigation of the sector on Monday.

“The failure of the banks to fully pass on the recent rate cuts to their customers when their cost of funds have come down significantly, leaves them exposed to the charge that they are putting their profits before their customers,'' Mr Frydenberg said.

“This is not a good outcome for either their customers or the economy as a whole, and comes just months after the royal commission shone a bright light on misconduct in the banking sector.

No collusion

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has been tasked with examining the pricing of mortgage pricing and other areas.

Advertisement

Prasad Patkar, portfolio manager at Platypus Asset Management said: "There is market concentration and there is pricing power but I don't think that the banks are colluding, they are just reacting to the same event - falling interest rates."

The Reserve Bank has sought to shore up the Australian economy by cutting interest rates this year, with three cuts since June taking the cash rate down to a record low of 0.75 per cent by October’s meeting.

Banks haven’t passed on the full rate cuts to customers, however, with owner-occupiers receiving an average of 57 basis points out of the 75 basis points of official rate cuts.

I'm cautious about their margins and that leads me to be cautious about the sector. — Jason Kururangi, Aberdeen Standard Investments

The banks blamed ultra-low interest rates for their decision to not pass on the interest rate cuts in full. As official interest rates fall closer to zero, the banks say they cannot recoup lower lending rates from depositors who are already accepting interest rates at or near zero.

But the banks have come under fire because, as they compete aggressively for new loans, a gap has opened up between the rate they offer to lure new customers relative to the rates paid by longer standing loyal customers.

Rock and a hard place

"It feels as if we are going over ground that was covered in the Royal Commission last year. Twelve months ago, everyone was talking about front book versus back book," said Jason Kururangi, investment manager at Aberdeen Standard Investments.

Advertisement

"I think that it's very hard for someone to legislate how banks price," he said. "That brings more challenges."

"I feel like the banks are caught between a rock and a hard place," the fund manager added. "The lower interest rates go, the harder it gets to maintain profit levels."

"I'm cautious about their margins and that leads me to be cautious about the sector."

The outlook for the banks likely depends on the monetary policy and what the Reserve Bank intends to do going forward, Mr Kururangi said.

"If they went down the quantitative easing path, it would depend on how that would be structured. I would say, however, that it would be more positive if we saw some more fiscal spending from the government.

"It's potentially why the Treasurer is having a crack at the banks. If more of the interest rate cut was passed through, it would free up a lot of cash for the consumer to potentially put some money back into the economy."

In such a scenario, the need for fiscal spending may not be so pressing, Mr Kururangi said.

One form of stimulus is not on the fund manager's policy preference list, however, and that's negative interest rates.

"I would prefer not to enter a world of negative interest rates. European banks have underperformed. Some of that is self-inflicted but at the same time it's hard to generate returns in an environment of low interest rates."

Mr Patkar added: "Zero bound in where people fear what happens next."
description: Investors remain cautious about the banks, which are under pressure from lower interest rates and near-permanent political scrutiny.
